evidence.detectionMethod: Homozygosity mapping revealed no significant homozygous regions. Linkage identified shared genotype encompassing DFNB84 locus.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Hereditary hearing loss is characterized by a high degree of genetic heterogeneity. Here we present OTOGL mutations, a homozygous one base pair deletion (c.1430 delT) causing a frameshift (p.Val477Glufs(∗)25) in a large consanguineous family and two compound heterozygous mutations, c.547C>T (p.Arg183(∗)) and c.5238+5G>A, in a nonconsanguineous family with moderate nonsyndromic sensorineural hearing loss. OTOGL maps to the DFNB84 locus at 12q21.31 and encodes otogelin-like, which has structural similarities to the epithelial-secreted mucin protein family. We demonstrate that Otogl is expressed in the inner ear of vertebrates with a transcription level that is high in embryonic, lower in neonatal, and much lower in adult stages. Otogelin-like is localized to the acellular membranes of the cochlea and the vestibular system and to a variety of inner ear cells located underneath these membranes. Knocking down of otogl with morpholinos in zebrafish leads to sensorineural hearing loss and anatomical changes in the inner ear, supporting that otogelin-like is essential for normal inner ear function. We propose that OTOGL mutations affect the production and/or function of acellular structures of the inner ear, which ultimately leads to sensorineural hearing loss.
dc:source.dc:creator: Yariz KO
dc:source.dc:title: Mutations in OTOGL, encoding the inner ear protein otogelin-like, cause moderate sensorineural hearing loss.

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 2 Proband

evidence.dc:description: Minigene assay of splice variant demonstrated skipping of exon 43 (out of frame). Nonsense present in 8 europeans (0.00007) and 1 African in gnomAD. Splice variant absent from gnomAD.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Hearing impairment is characterized by great genetic heterogeneity. We report the identification, by whole exome sequencing, of two different nonsense mutations (c.1558C>T; p.Gln520 and c.2773C>T; p.Arg925) in the otogelin-like gene (OTOGL), in a child affected by mild to moderate isolated deafness. Parental genotypes allowed us to conclude that these mutations are present in the compound heterozygous state in the patient. In addition, our clinical data establish that the tectorial membrane and/or the outer hair cells are defective in this form of deafness.
dc:source.dc:creator: Bonnet C
dc:source.dc:title: Biallelic nonsense mutations in the otogelin-like gene (OTOGL) in a child affected by mild to moderate hearing impairment.

evidence.dc:description: Variants were confirmed in trans. p.Gln520X is present in 2 European alleles in gnomAD. p.Arg925X is present in 7 European alleles in gnomAD.
All affecteds were homozygous. Another homozygous missense variant was 3' to frameshift, so not predicted to affect protein. Variant is present in 1 European allele in gnomAD.

dc:source.dc:abstract: This study was designed to delineate genetic contributions, if any, to sporadic forms of mild to moderate sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) not related to GJB2 mutations (DFNB1) in a pediatric population.
dc:source.dc:creator: Kim NK
dc:source.dc:title: Whole-exome sequencing reveals diverse modes of inheritance in sporadic mild to moderate sensorineural hearing loss in a pediatric population.

evidence.dc:description: Both variants are absent from gnomAD.

dc:source.dc:abstract: To screen for the genetic basis of congenital hearing loss in a Syrian family.
dc:source.dc:creator: Barake R
dc:source.dc:title: The OTOGL p.Arg925* Variant is Associated with Moderate Hearing Loss in a Syrian Nonconsanguineous Family.

evidence.dc:description: Variant is present in 7 European alleles in gnomAD.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Autosomal recessive non-syndromic hearing loss (DFNB) is a genetically heterogeneous disorder. So far, 55 pathogenic genes have been identified. In this study, we aim to characterize the clinical feature and the genetic cause of a Chinese DFNB family.
dc:source.dc:creator: Gu X
dc:source.dc:title: Novel biallelic OTOGL mutations in a Chinese family with moderate non-syndromic sensorineural hearing loss.

evidence.dc:description: p.Ser2156X variant is present in 4/1610 (0.25%) East Asian alleles in gnomAD. p.Ser2159MetfsX2 variant is absent from gnomAD.

Expression of OTOGL detected in human fetal and adult inner ear. Also expressed in heart, skeletal muscle, kidney, spleen, brain, retina, and duodenum. Immunolocalization performed in mouse and rat, in situ hybridization in mouse and antibody, and RT-PCR in mouse provided consistent expression pattern in cochlea.
evidence.rdfs:label: Yariz Expression

evidence.dc:description: Deep mRNA sequencing of organs of corti of P7 mice revealed Otogl expression at levels comparable to Otog, Myo7a, and Otof. Similar results in E16.5 mice.
evidence.rdfs:label: Bonnet Expression

evidence.dc:description: Two different morphants significantly knocked down expression of otogl. Utricular otolith size not affected, but development of semicircular canals was disrupted. Significantly smaller microphonic responses of morphants suggest hearing loss due to LoF of Otogl
evidence.rdfs:label: Yariz Animal Model

evidence.dc:description: downgraded to 1 point. Off-target effects of MOs not investigated

dc:description: The OTOGL​ gene has been associated with autosomal recessive nonsyndromic hearing loss using the ClinGen Clinical Validity Framework as of 10/5/2017​. This association was made using case-level data only. At least 10​ variants (nonsense, frameshift, splice) have been reported in humans. OTOGL​ was first associated with this disease in humans as early as 2012​ (Yariz et al.​). Association is seen in at least 6​ probands in 5​ publications (23122586, 23850727, 25829320, ​25719458, 28426234). Variants in this gene segregated with disease in 9​ additional family members. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 pts.) has been reached. This gene-disease association is supported by a zebrafish model and expression studies. In summary, OTOGL​ is definitively associated with autosomal recessive nonsyndromic hearing loss. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Hearing Loss Working Group on 1/5/2018​.
